results.title: Bobby and the Birchip Leisure Centre
results.creator_credit: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: The Birchip Leisure Centre is the social hub of Birchip township and surrounds. In addition to providing clubrooms for the local football, hockey, netball, golf and tennis clubs, the leisure centre also plays host to social events and functions. What is key to the centre is the fact that it is community built and funded - everyone in the local area collaborated to raise money and build the facilities. Here the manager, Bobby Liston, gives a personal view of this important place.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development

Here the manager, Bobby Liston, gives a personal view of this important place.

results.title: Birchip Historical Society
results.creator_credit: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: Containing a treasure trove of artefacts and memories, the Birchip Historical Society museum is maintained and staffed by hardworking volunteers from the area. Here Dorothy Reid, Harry Rickard and Ken Kemp talk about some memorable objects and the importance of the Historical Society to the community’s wellbeing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development

results.title: The Birchip boy who became a legend
results.creator_credit: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: An intimate portrait of 84-year-old Roger Hogan, aka Australian Country music legend ‘Dusty Rankin’. Born and raised in Birchip, Dusty appeared on Australia’s Amateur Hour in 1946 and maintained an active career through to 1961 when he returned to working the farm full-time. He was one of the most popular country artists of the time, with many of his songs becoming popular standards. Here Roger remembers his rich life of touring but ultimately brings it all back home.
results.title_for_label: The Birchip boy who became a legend
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development

results.title: The Birchip Cropping Group
results.creator_credit: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: A background history of the Birchip Cropping Group, an agricultural research and extension organisation covering the Wimmera Mallee region set up to assist farmers in crop production. Its philosophy is to produce food that is clean, safe and green. Presented by Alexandra, Fiona, James, Simon and the BCG.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development

results.title: Selected works from "Bute utes: the movie"
results.brief_description:
A selection of 9 narrative works from across regional Victoria by various storytellers.
Produced by Regional Arts Victoria, ACE Connections, East Gippsland Aboriginal Arts Corporation, Robinvale Cultural Festival and Network House, The South-West Institute of TAFE and the Tarerer Gunditj Association and supported by The Regional Arts Fund, The Myer Foundation and VicHealth.

results.title: We used to call them Blackboys
results.creator_credit: Goulburn Ovens Institute of TAFE and Maz McGann
results.brief_description: Using photographic images, this story of the grass trees growing on the ranges outside Wangaratta becomes a poetic meditation on how a person’s ideas on place can change with understanding and compassion. European insensitivity and ignorance of the past has been replaced with political awareness and correctness, a sense of the land and the environment and a desire for reconciliation with those who belonged to the land before the invasion of the white man. A sensitive and thought-provoking piece. Made as part of Regional Arts Victoria’s Bute Utes - the Movie program.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Goulburn Ovens Institute of TAFE and Maz McGann
results.description: Using photographic images, this story of the grass trees growing on the ranges outside Wangaratta becomes a poetic meditation on how a person’s ideas on place can change with understanding and compassion. European insensitivity and ignorance of the past has been replaced with political awareness and correctness, a sense of the land and the environment and a desire for reconciliation with those who belonged to the land before the invasion of the white man. A sensitive and thought-provoking piece. Made as part of Regional Arts Victoria’s Bute Utes - the Movie program.

results.title: Road trip: after the Gippsland bushfires 2003
results.brief_description:
A road trip through the East Gippsland region of Victoria after the bushfires in 2003 and a chance meeting at a place called Seldom Seen, somewhere between Jindabyne and Buchan, with David Woodburn owner of the “Seldom Seen Service Statiion”. David talks of his encounter with the fires, his loss of his family home, the service station and many of his pet animals including an emu and an ostrich. But it is David’s eccentricity and sardonic humour, along with the wonderful quirky photographic shots that makes this story so engaging and appealing.
Created as part of the “Bute Utes the Movie” project in association with Regional Arts Victoria.
